block.p: BP Chief Resigns After Losing Battle to Conceal Gay Lover The British magnate John Browne, who as its chief executive transformed BP into one of the most successful global oil companies, resigned abruptly after losing a court battle with a London tabloid over disclosure of his sexual relationship with a younger man. Mr. Browne admitted having made false statements to a court during hearings on the case.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

Castro Missing on May Day The throngs were out in the streets of Havana as they always are on May Day, but Cuba's holiday honoring workers came and went without Fidel Castro. Despite speculation, he did not make his first public appearance since undergoing emergency surgery nine months ago.
PAGE A3

Checking Up on Gun Buyers Momentum is building in Congress behind a measure that would push states to report their mental health records to the federal database used to conduct background checks on gun buyers.
PAGE A16

Shaken, Stirred and Satisfied What makes the perfect martini? The perfect gin. The Dining section's tasting panel sampled 20 to find the best for mixing the most famous (and perhaps least understood) cocktail. It found that some striking gins do not make great martinis.
DINING, PAGE F1

Injury Foils Yanks' No-Hit Bid The rookie Phil Hughes, in his second start, had not allowed a hit when he came out of the game against the Texas Rangers in the seventh inning, with a leg injury. The Yankees won, 10-1.
SPORTSWEDNESDAY, PAGE D1

Book Criticism, Condensed Across the country, newspapers are cutting book sections or relying more on reprints of reviews from news agencies or larger papers. Some consider this a sign of a withering literary culture, but others are more hopeful.
THE ARTS, PAGE E1

Crowds Rally for Immigrants' Rights Tens of thousands of people pressing for immigrants' rights demonstrated in dozens of places, including Union Square in New York, but the crowds paled in comparison with last year's turnouts.
